title: Sinusoidal Modeling - Orbit of Venus - Part B

content.description:
The planet Venus orbits the Sun every <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>225</mn> </math> days. Because of its elliptical orbit, the distance between Venus and the Sun periodically increases and decreases. The maximum distance of Venus from the Sun is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>108.9</mn> </math> million kilometers, and the minimum distance of Venus from the Sun is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>107.5</mn> </math> million kilometers. The planet reaches each of its maximum distance and minimum distance from the Sun once every <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>225</mn> </math> days.

The sinusoidal function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>D</mn> </math>, given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>D</mi> <mtext> </mtext> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>cos</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>b</mi> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mi>c</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44D7@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, models the distance, in millions of kilometers, between Venus and the Sun as a function of time <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>t</mn> </math>, in days. Based on the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>D</mn> </math>, Venus is at its maximum distance from the Sun at time <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadshacqGH9aqpcaaIWaaaaa@3902@</annotation> </semantics> </math> days.
content.question:
Part B

Based on the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>D</mi> </math>, Venus is at its minimum distance from the Sun at time <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>112.5</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadshacqGH9aqpcaaIXaGaaGymaiaaikdacaGGUaGaaGynaaaa@3BEB@</annotation> </semantics> </math> days. Let <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow><mo>[</mo> <mrow> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>,</mo><msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> <mo>]</mo></mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3CC0@</annotation> </semantics> </math> represent the time interval between when Venus is at its maximum distance from the Sun and when Venus is at its minimum distance from the Sun.

(i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the distance, in millions of kilometers per day, over the time interval <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow><mo>[</mo> <mrow> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>,</mo><msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> <mo>]</mo></mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3CC0@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(ii) Interpret the meaning of your answer from (i) in the context of the problem.

(iii) Use the average rate of change found in (i) to estimate the distance of Venus from the Sun, in millions of kilometers, at time <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>40</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadshacqGH9aqpcaaIWaaaaa@3902@</annotation> </semantics> </math> days. Show the work that leads to your answer.

frqParts.text:
Part B

Based on the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>D</mi> </math>, Venus is at its minimum distance from the Sun at time <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>112.5</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadshacqGH9aqpcaaIXaGaaGymaiaaikdacaGGUaGaaGynaaaa@3BEB@</annotation> </semantics> </math> days. Let <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow><mo>[</mo> <mrow> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>,</mo><msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> <mo>]</mo></mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3CC0@</annotation> </semantics> </math> represent the time interval between when Venus is at its maximum distance from the Sun and when Venus is at its minimum distance from the Sun.

(i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the distance, in millions of kilometers per day, over the time interval <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mrow><mo>[</mo> <mrow> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>,</mo><msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> <mo>]</mo></mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3CC0@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(ii) Interpret the meaning of your answer from (i) in the context of the problem.

(iii) Use the average rate of change found in (i) to estimate the distance of Venus from the Sun, in millions of kilometers, at time <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>40</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadshacqGH9aqpcaaIWaaaaa@3902@</annotation> </semantics> </math> days. Show the work that leads to your answer.

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Express functions, equations, or expressions in analytically equivalent forms that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context.
